docs.lead_paragraph: A new study of hepatitis C suggests that available treatments may reverse some of the liver damage from the disease, at least for younger patients. Four million Americans are thought to be infected with the virus that causes hepatitis C, and the disease is the leading reason for liver transplants.
docs.abstract: Research led by Dr Thierry Poynard of University of Paris, published in journal Gastroenterology, finds that available treatments may reverse some liver damage from hepatitis C in younger patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What do you do for an encore after you have decoded the human genome? Dr. J. Craig Venter has had to ponder that problem sooner than he expected after being forced out as president of Celera Genomics in January. He has now made his decision, to start two institutes and to write a book. One institute, he said in an interview last week before giving a lecture at the Yale School of Medicine, will study issues of science policy like the genetic basis of race and stem cell research. The other will try to engineer microbes genetically to convert carbon dioxide into hydrogen, producing clean energy and averting greenhouse warming in the same step.

headline.main: Thrown Aside, Genome Pioneer Plots a Rebound

docs.abstract: Article on Dr J Craig Venter, pioneer in decoding human genome who has been forced out as president of Celera Genomics; Venter, in interview, says he hopes to start two scientific institutes and write book on genomics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Recently one morning, I received an urgent call from the mother of an 18-year-old named Daniel, whom I treat for marijuana abuse. For most of the past few years, Daniel had smoked more than a quarter of an ounce of marijuana daily and was almost always high, except, perhaps, when he was asleep.
docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel Cases column on 18-year-old named Daniel who is addicted to marijuana (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: While there are more heat deaths in the summer than at any other time, individual hot days in the spring may kill more people than an equally hot day in July or August, a new British study suggests. The study, published this month in The Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, also found that temperatures as low as 66 degrees Fahrenheit began to add measurably to deaths in London, according to a review of 20 years' worth of records.
docs.abstract: Study led by Dr Shakoor Hajat of London School of Hygiene and Tropical Health, published in Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, finds that individual hot days in spring may kill more people than equally hot days in summer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, an examination of five years of birth records from Europe found that the farther south a mother lived, the greater the odds that she would give birth to a boy. The researcher who studied the records, Dr. Victor E. Grech of St. Luke's Hospital in Malta, suggested that temperature might play a role in determining a baby's sex, and made plans to review a much larger collection of data. This week, Dr. Grech reported in The British Medical Journal the results of a review of more than 500 million birth records over 50 years in Europe and North America.
docs.abstract: Dr Victor E Grech of St Luke's Hospital in Malta, after reviewing European birth records, had previously suggested that temperature may play a role in determining a baby's sex; reviewing larger collection of birth records from Europe and North America, he now concludes that temperature does not play role; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It may seem improbable that a disorder first described in the medical literature in 1882 is still little known and poorly understood and more often than not misdiagnosed. That disorder is cyclic vomiting syndrome, or C.V.S., a very distressing, life-disrupting condition that experts once considered rare but now say is far more common than previously realized.

headline.main: Cyclic Vomiting: A Century in Doctors' Blind Spot

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on little known and poorly understood disorder called cyclic vomiting syndrome; notes experts say life-disrupting condition, once considered rare, is far more common than previously realized and affects adults as well as children; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Snoring can be a sign of something much more serious, and George Resto's wife at the time, Sonia, was worried. ''She used to tell me I was snoring a lot, really loud,'' Mr. Resto, 39, of the Bronx, said. ''But she was concerned because I also couldn't breathe. I would just gag and gasp for air over and over again.''

headline.main: New Treatments May Help Control Sleep Apnea

docs.abstract: Article describes improvements in diagnosis and treatment of sleep apnea, including less expensive home sleep studies, weight loss, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machines, dental appliances, palate surgery and radio frequency tongue reduction; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The patient is 60, and she has been happily taking estrogen for 20 years, ever since her uterus and ovaries were removed. Now, she would like to stop. But when she tries, she is miserable. Hot flashes leave her drenched in sweat, sometimes as often as every half hour, and she seems to be getting more uncomfortable every day. Much as she wants to get off the hormone, she tells her doctor, ''Right now, I'm ready to just scream and say, 'Oh, please, just put me back on it.' ''

headline.main: Weighing Risks and Benefits of Hormone Therapy

docs.abstract: Article, in light of recent warnings about possible risks of long-term hormone replacement therapy in post-menopausal women, weighs therapy's benefits and risks, including breast cancer; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Karla Miller rushed to the Woman's Hospital of Texas with sudden labor pains on the morning of Aug. 17, 1990, she was little more than five months pregnant. Doctors at the Houston hospital told Ms. Miller and her husband, Mark, that the fetus was at the very edge of viability, 23 weeks old, the minimum age for having any chance of survival outside the womb.

headline.main: Eyes of Texas Fasten on Life, Death and the Premature Infant

docs.abstract: Article on suit brought by Karla and Mark Miller against HCA Inc, owner of Woman's Hospital in Houston, Tex; Millers say they, not hospital, should have been entitled to make decision not to resuscitate their now 11-year-old daughter, Sidney, who was born 23 weeks premature and has cerebral palsy, is nearly blind and severely retarded; Texas Supreme Court is hearing case; photos (M)

byline.original: By DANA WECHSLER LINDEN and MIA WECHSLER DORON

docs.lead_paragraph: Every year thousands of patients with digestive problems undergo endoscopy, the examination of the gastric tract through a tube lowered down the throat, to look for signs of ulcers. But a study published on Saturday in The British Medical Journal finds that a breath test for the presence of the bacteria that cause ulcers is just as good as the invasive endoscopy at making the diagnosis.

headline.main: Easy Way to Find Ulcers: Breathe

docs.abstract: Study by researchers at Western Infirmary in Glasgow, published in British Medical Journal, finds that breath test for presence of bacteria that causes ulcers is as effective as invasive endoscopy; drawing (M)
